div1.p: United States District Court Western District of Washington Northern Division.
In the Matter of the Application of Ching Hing for a Writ of Habeas Corpus. } NO. 2875 Reply Memorandum Brief

I will not burden this Honorable Court with a lengthy Answer to the argument presented by the Learned Counsel for the Government in the last Memorandum Brief filed by him, but will simply reiterate the stand I took in open court before your Honor, that an issue having been made upon the record in this case, the Court should then determine what was the statute of the detained at the time the issue was made up. Therefore, it resolves itself into this question - did Mr. Denamore, at the time he affirmed the decision of Commissioner White, act without authority?

Your Honor has allowed us to ask by interrogatory of the Assistant Secretary, if he was in Washington at that time. Mr. Justice Gould hass upheld the right to obtain this information from the Assistant Secretary in the decision which your Honor has before you. Therefore, it would seem to me that the only orderly procedure in upholding the dignity of your Honor's Court, and the dignity of the District Court, presided over by Mr. Justice Gould, would be that your Honor must allow this case to take the orderly couse of procedure; or if your Honor feels that the Government has, by its pleadings, admitted that Mr. Denamore acted without authority at the time he did act, then make such a decision, in either dismissing the alien, or sending the record back for review by the proper officer, to wit: - the Secretary or Assistant Secretary.

To allow counsel at this time to amend his return, after the issue has been made, would be to subvert the course of justice and orderly procedure of this Court. As Mr. Justice Dooling said in a decision before your Honor, that the detained has a right to 1.
have his plea heard by the proper officer. This was ratified by Mr. Justice Gould in his decision, and I think your Honor should follow this ruling and not allow any arbitrary action taken after the issues are made up, and more especially, I may say, without even asking permission of this Court to allow the same ot be taken, but to come in on the morning of the hearing, as was done in this case, and make a return after a prior return had been made, and the issue then made up to ask your Honor to dismiss the case when the first return showed that the original record was before this Court. In my estimation it would be denying to this detained the rights allowed by law and the treaties between nations.

For a moment let me cite an illustration which might occur if this rule of procedure was allowed to exist. Mr. Denamore might act at such times as he saw fit, regardless of whether the Secretary and Assistant Secretary were present or not; the detained might apply for a Writ of Habeas Corpus, might prepare his defense and meet the issues, and then Counsel for the Government could come in and say in each and every case - "It is true that Mr. Denamore has acted without authority, but all we have to do is to have a carbon copy of the proceedings before the Court and wire the Secretary to affirm the COmmissioner's decision, show this to the Court and the case falls."

It would seem to me that it would place a man in this position under the original facts, as in this case - he would have a right to present a case where one had deprived hm of his liberty without authority, he would have to engage counsel at an expense, file papers at a further expense, and then the Immigration Department could hold for naught orderly and regular proceedure, and act at the eleventh hour without notice, without giving counsel for the detained, the right to present sound argument to the Secretary in favor of the detained, and deprive the detained of his libery, and hold for naught the inalienable right of habeas corpus procedure, and equitable and just hearing upon the issue made when 2.
the Writ was issued and return made by the Government, and the case, upon those facts, properly placed before this Court.

I sincerely trust that your Honor will not tire of the effort I have made in behalf of this poor Chinaman, but will grant to him the protection ofthe strong arm of this Court, in order that this Chinaman may have granted unto him such orderly procedure and such rights as we would want an American citizen granted were he before a tribunal of a foreign Court, seeking what this Chinaman seeks - simple justice;
And I, Therefore, respectfully pray that your Honor will deny the petition and demand of the Governmnet, and will make such order in this case, as to your Honor may seem just and equitable.
In the SuperiorDistrict Court StateWestern District of Washington King County Northern Division
In the Matter of the Application of Ching Hing for a Writ of Habeas Corpus.
Beeler & Sullivan Lawyers 510-11 White Building Seattle, Wash.
